Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Encrypted Virus Nanoparticles for Targeted Gene Delivery
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 0955536 PI: Suh, Junghae ORG: Rice University

Title: CAREER: Encrypted Virus Nanoparticles for Targeted Gene Delivery

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Delivering nucleic acid-based therapeutics into target cells specifically is a considerable challenge. Current approaches to achieving targeted gene delivery are limited to modifying the delivery vectors to recognize particular cell surface receptors. Unfortunately, in certain diseases, such as breast cancer, chances of finding a specific cell surface biomarker that identifies all cancer cells are low. Thus, a therapeutic that targets a single cell surface receptor will likely face difficulties in achieving specificity. As a potentially superior alternative approach, the PI proposes to develop innovative virus based gene delivery vectors that are able to compute multiple biomolecular signatures, which in combination are unique to breast cancer, to achieve improved targeting and delivery of nucleic acid therapeutics into breast cancer cells. The virus nanoparticles will be programmed to detect the presence of enzymes misregulated in cancer. A collection of virus nanoparticles encoded with high levels of biomolecular encryption will be developed. The nanoparticles will "unlock" only upon sensing the correct combination of enzymatic inputs preset for identity and intensity. Only successfully unlocked virus capsids will go on to deliver their therapeutic payload into the cell nucleus. Rational and combinatorial design approaches will be used in synergy to engineer virus scaffolds whose bioactivities are actuated by single inputs or by dual inputs under a defined Boolean logic operator. Such sophisticated gene delivery vectors should yield improved therapeutic outcomes. The impact of this research extends far beyond the gene delivery field. The creation of advanced genetically encoded nanoparticles that are able to sense complex stimuli and respond with desired programmed functions can be used as the active components of a number of technologies that already depend on the capabilities of nanoparticles. Nanomaterials able to conduct such complex biomolecular information processing can be very useful for numerous applications, ranging from biomedicine to national defense. This novel technology will enhance the current technical possibilities of nanoscale devices.

BROADER IMPACTS: The PI proposes a highly integrated high school to graduate level training, education, and outreach program centered on educating students about viruses and their exciting place in bionanotechnology. Diversity has been incorporated with care throughout the research and educational plan. The PI will leverage the developed networks of several key organizations, including NSF-funded Center for Biological and Environmental Nanotechnology (CBEN) and Alliances for Graduate Education in the Professoriate (AGEP), to reach large numbers of underrepresented students through lectures, informal lunch meetings, and lab tours and demonstrations. High school and undergraduate students will be exposed to the emerging technologies built from viruses and will be given the opportunity to conduct research in the PIs laboratory. The PI will provide extensive mentorship to students to guide them towards a successful future in science and engineering. Knowledge and inventions derived from the PIs research will be incorporated into a new graduate level course, "Viruses for Bionanotechnology", as well as into the lectures aimed at high school and undergraduate students. Importantly, the PIs graduate students will be trained to become conscientious future mentors aware of the importance of diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

This NSF project has enabled the creation of a platform of viruses activated by proteases that are elevated at sites of disease. The protease-activatable viruses (PAV) are based on a benign virus called the adeno-associated virus (AAV). By inserting small protease-sensitive peptide motifs, or“peptide locks”, into the virus capsid, the vectors lose the ability to infect cells unless the locks are cleaved off the virus shell by the proteases. The CAREER Award project aimed to develop PAVs for the treatment of breast cancer, as proteases are elevated in breast tumor microenvironments. When the engineered virus comes across a tumor, enzymes in the tumor microenvironment should be able to “switch on” the virus, activating it to bind to the tumor cells and deliver the toxic nucleic acid cargo it was carrying. Although this project is aimed specifically at treating breast cancer, many other pathologies also share the feature of having altered protease activities at diseased sites, thereby making the platform broadly useful. The PAV platform technology is now being applied to the treatment of a variety of diseases, such as cancer, heart diseases, and neurological diseases.

The research carried out under this project has been disseminated through multiple means, including publication in peer-reviewed journals (three primary research papers, two review papers, and two more in preparation), and nine podium presentations and eleven poster presentations at various scientific conferences. The PI has also given 38 invited talks at various universities and research institutions discussing the results of the work. To move the developed technology closer to commercialization, a non-provisional patent application has been filed on the PAV platform. Depending on the results of future preclinical experiments, attempts will be made to commercialize the platform technology either through licensing to a biotech company or initiating a startup company.

Broader impacts

As more virus-based and gene-based therapies transition from the academic setting to the clinic, society will begin to understand that just because something is genetically modified does not mean it is guaranteed to be dangerous. In stark contrast, genetic approaches can greatly improve the health status of humanity, improving the quality of life of people around the globe. Through more technological successes and better education of the general public, the PI aims to bring hope to patients suffering from terminal or debilitating chronic illnesses and make the public less afraid of technology as a whole.

The project has directly funded the training of eight PhD students, five being female and two being underrepresented minority students, in advanced scientific research. It has also directly funded the training of eight undergraduate students, four being female, in scientific research. Furthermore, six high school students have been exposed to introductory research. Overall, the project has supported the PI’s effort in mentoring 42 undergraduate students in research (~50% female and ~30% underrepresented minority). The PI’s graduate students have all participated in mentoring undergraduate and high school students.

The PI has actively participated in various public outreach opportunities. The PI partnered with multiple museums in Houston to expose the general public to science and technology. Specifically, she served as a consultant for the Chemistry Exhibit at the Houston Natural Science Museum and recorded a video on Self-Assembly. She also served as a consultant for the Houston Children’s Museum and helped develop a children’s activity for the new Synthetic Biology exhibit.
